The Congress recognizes the devastating impact of fraudulent activity on the elderly, who are disproportionately targeted by deceptive tactics. Elderly citizens, representing 12.5% of the population, account for 30% of fraud victims and are more vulnerable to questionable sales practices due to increased accessibility. Schemes to bilk the elderly involve selling inferior, unnecessary, and sometimes nonexistent products, robbing them of savings and dignity. Fraudulent activities like phony vacations and credit repair services target the elderly, who are highly vulnerable to consumer fraud. These practices tarnish the reputation of legitimate businesses. SEC. 2. FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. The Federal Trade Commission will participate in the Financial Crimes Enforcement Center and receive law enforcement products. Venue rules in the Federal Trade Commission Act are amended to allow for parties to be summoned regardless of their location. Criminal contempt authority in the Act is also amended. The Trade Commission Act is amended to allow for criminal contempt actions for violations of orders obtained in cases brought under section 13(b) of the Act. The Commission can initiate these cases on its own or assist a court in enforcing orders. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for fraud and deceit to increase offense levels based on the number of victims. Guidelines for vulnerable victims will also be amended to increase offense levels by 7 if the offender knew the victim was vulnerable. Mandatory restitution is also required. SEC. 4 amends the order of restitution to make it mandatory under title 18, United States Code. SEC. 5 addresses the National Telemarketing Fraud Working Group. SEC. 6 mandates the designation of 50 attorneys for prosecuting consumer fraud and supporting consumer fraud education programs. It takes effect upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 deals with forfeitures. In SEC. 7, civil forfeiture procedures are amended in relation to offenses involving crimes against individuals aged 55 years. The amendment allows for up to 25 percent of forfeited amounts from crimes against individuals 55 years or older to be used for victim restitution. Additionally, individuals convicted of certain offenses affecting older individuals must forfeit property obtained from the violation. SEC. 8. MONEY LAUNDERING.

Amends Section 1956(c)(7)(D) of title 18, United States Code to include fraud relating to access devices.

SEC. 9. UNIFORM LAWS GOVERNING LICENSING.

The Attorney General will prepare model State laws for licensing home repair contractors, mortgage companies, and prize giveaway companies.

SEC. 10. MAIL FRAUD. Amendment to Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code expands the definition of offense to include private courier services. Section 1346 is amended to define "private courier service" as a private entity providing services similar to the Postal Service.
